title: Goldberg polyhedron
text:
In <a href="mathematics">mathematics</a>, and more specifically in <a href="polyhedral%20combinatorics">polyhedral combinatorics</a>, a Goldberg polyhedron is a convex <a href="polyhedron">polyhedron</a> made from hexagons and pentagons. They were first described in 1937 by <a href="Michael%20Goldberg%20%28mathematician%29">Michael Goldberg</a> (1902–1990). They are defined by three properties: each face is either a pentagon or hexagon, exactly three faces meet at each vertex, and they have <a href="rotational%20icosahedral%20symmetry">rotational icosahedral symmetry</a>. They are not necessarily mirror-symmetric; e.g. "GP"(5,3) and "GP"(3,5) are <a href="enantiomorph">enantiomorph</a>s of each other. A Goldberg polyhedron is a <a href="dual%20polyhedron">dual polyhedron</a> of a <a href="geodesic%20sphere">geodesic sphere</a>.
A consequence of <a href="Euler%27s%20polyhedron%20formula">Euler's polyhedron formula</a> is that a Goldberg polyhedron always has exactly twelve pentagonal faces. Icosahedral symmetry ensures that the pentagons are always <a href="regular%20polygon">regular</a> and that there are always 12 of them. If the vertices are not constrained to a sphere, the polyhedron can be constructed with planar equilateral (but not in general equiangular) faces.
Simple examples of Goldberg polyhedra include the <a href="dodecahedron">dodecahedron</a> and <a href="truncated%20icosahedron">truncated icosahedron</a>. Other forms can be described by taking a <a href="chess">chess</a> <a href="Knight%20%28chess%29">knight</a> move from one pentagon to the next: first take "m" steps in one direction, then turn 60° to the left and take "n" steps. Such a polyhedron is denoted "GP"("m","n"). A dodecahedron is "GP"(1,0) and a truncated icosahedron is "GP"(1,1).
A similar technique can be applied to construct polyhedra with <a href="tetrahedral%20symmetry">tetrahedral symmetry</a> and <a href="octahedral%20symmetry">octahedral symmetry</a>. These polyhedra will have triangles or squares rather than pentagons. These variations are given Roman numeral subscripts denoting the number of sides on the non-hexagon faces: GPIII("n","m"), GPIV("n","m"), and GPV("n","m").
Elements.
The number of vertices, edges, and faces of "GP"("m","n") can be computed from "m" and "n", with "T" = "m"2 + "mn" + "n"2 = ("m" + "n")2 − "mn", depending on one of three symmetry systems: 
The number of non-hexagonal faces can be determined using the Euler characteristic, as demonstrated <a href="Euler%20characteristic%23Soccer_ball">here</a>.
Construction.
Most Goldberg polyhedra can be constructed using <a href="Conway%20polyhedron%20notation">Conway polyhedron notation</a> starting with (T)etrahedron, (C)ube, and (D)odecahedron seeds. The <a href="Chamfer%20%28geometry%29">chamfer</a> operator, "c", replaces all edges by hexagons, transforming "GP"("m","n") to "GP"(2"m",2"n"), with a "T" multiplier of 4. The "truncated kis" operator, "y" = "tk", generates "GP"(3,0), transforming "GP"("m","n") to "GP"(3"m",3"n"), with a "T" multiplier of 9.
For class 2 forms, the "dual kis" operator, "z" = "dk", transforms "GP"("a",0) into "GP"("a","a"), with a "T" multiplier of 3. For class 3 forms, the "whirl" operator, "w", generates "GP"(2,1), with a "T" multiplier of 7. A clockwise and counterclockwise whirl generator, "w" = "wrw" generates "GP"(7,0) in class 1. In general, a whirl can transform a GP("a","b") into GP("a" + 3"b",2"ab") for "a" > "b" and the same chiral direction. If chiral directions are reversed, GP("a","b") becomes GP(2"a" + 3"b","a" − 2"b") if "a" ≥ 2"b", and GP(3"a" + "b",2"b" − "a") if "a" < 2"b".
